messageBody:
## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 24, 2021 - March 30, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-03-31T20:44:16Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-03-24T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-03-30T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210331-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.    

Geomagnetic activity reached minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2021-03-25T00:00Z-03:00Z. This enhanced geomagnetic activity is associated with a S-type (<500 km/s) CME arrival. The CME was first visible in the coronagraph imagery on 2021-03-20T00:48Z and was detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2021-03-24T19:18Z.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt was elevated above the threshold level of 1000 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period (see notification 20210325-AL-001). These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with the arrival of the S-type CME mentioned above. A weaker transient signature was also detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2021-03-24T04:57Z that may have contributed to the increase in the energetic electron flux.  The electron fluxes went back to nominal levels around 2021-03-27.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the significantly elevated electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-03-31T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-04-06T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. Active regions 12811 and 12812 have decayed and are expected to rotate off of the Earth-facing disk during the early portion of the outlook period. Active regions 12811 and 12812 produced multiple A and B-class flares which may continue throughout the early portion of the next reporting period. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the next outlook period due to the possible arrival of high speed streams from a cluster of coronal holes centered around the Earth-facing disk's meridian on 2021-03-30. There is also a small coronal hole structure that may cause a high speed stream at STEREO-A during the early portion of the next reporting period.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-03-25T16:11:20Z
## Message ID: 20210325-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2021-03-25T13:50Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a CME with ID 2021-03-20T00:48:00-CME-001 and corresponding IPS with ID 2021-03-24T19:18:00-IPS-001.  A weaker transient signature was also detected around 2021-03-24T04:57Z that may have contributed to the increase.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-03-25T13:50:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 17, 2021 - March 23, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-03-24T20:09:49Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-03-17T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-03-23T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210324-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during the reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.

Geomagnetic activity reached moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 6 occurred during the synoptic period 2021-03-20T06:00Z-09:00Z (see notifications 20210320-AL-001 and 20210320-AL-002).  The cause of this enhanced geomagnetic activity is associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-03-19, with solar wind speeds reaching values around 680 km/s on 2021-03-21.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was elevated above the threshold level of 1000 pfu throughout most of the reporting period (see notifications 20210318-AL-001, 20210321-AL-001 and 20210323-AL-001). These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with the coronal hole high speed streams detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-03-13 and 2021-03-19, respectively.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the radiation belt enhancement mentioned above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-03-24T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-03-30T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. New Active Regions 2811 and 2812 rotated onto the Earth-facing disk near the end of the reporting period. There is one new active region due to rotate onto the Earth-facing disk early in the outlook period, as seen in STEREO-A EUVI imagery near S30E95 at the end of the reporting period. Active Region 2811 produced several B-class flares near the end of the reporting period and may continue to produce several B-class flares during the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity may vary between low and minor levels throughout the outlook period due to the possible influence of a coronal hole structure connected with the south pole coronal hole, which passed the Earth-facing meridian near the end of the reporting period.  This coronal hole structure may have affected STEREO A near the end of the reporting period, and may possibly become geoeffective near the middle of the outlook period. Electron flux levels may continue to remain elevated during the early part of the outlook period due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above detected at L1  on 2021-03-19.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-03-23T12:26:11Z
## Message ID: 20210323-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Continued elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2021-03-23T04:00Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2021-03-21T11:35Z are caused by the high speed stream starting on 2021-03-19, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 680 km/s.  The solar wind speed observed at L1 is currently around 510 km/s.  (See notification 20210321-AL-001.)

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-03-21T11:35:00-RBE-001.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-03-20T12:22:02Z
## Message ID: 20210320-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2021-03-20T06:00Z to 2021-03-20T09:00Z. 

The storm is caused by a high speed stream starting at 2021-03-19T19:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-03-20T06:00:00-GST-001.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 10, 2021 - March 16, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-03-17T21:31:45Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-03-10T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-03-16T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210317-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There was one C-type CME (see details below). Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA's Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME observed by SOHO LASCO C2 first seen in the SW at 2021-03-16T08:00Z would impact Parker Solar Probe at 2021-03-18T19:08Z and OSIRIS-REx (glancing blow) at 2021-03-19T12:00Z (plus or minus 7 hours) (see notification 20210317-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was below moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2021-03-14T03:00Z-06:00Z. This enhanced geomagnetic activity is associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2021-03-13, with solar wind speeds reaching values around 590 km/s on 2021-03-14.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt was elevated above the threshold level of 1000 pfu for part of the reporting period (see notifications 20210314-AL-001 and 20210316-AL-001). These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2021-03-13 as described above.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the radiation belt enhancement mentioned above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2021-03-16T11:09Z     ~514            C               165/-10               31                          STEREO A, SOHO                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-03-17T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-03-23T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. Active Regions AR2809 and AR2810 developed on the Earth-facing disk during the reporting period, with B- and C-class flares possible throughout the outlook period. STEREO-A may begin experiencing coronal hole high speed stream conditions at the beginning of the outlook period as indicated by the current position of the northern extension of the south pole coronal hole.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to minor throughout the outlook period, as the northern extension of the south pole coronal hole becomes geoeffective in a few days. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt is likely to remain elevated above the threshold level of 1000 pfu throughout the outlook period.

## No
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Parker Solar Probe, OSIRIS-REx)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-03-17T18:25:47Z
## Message ID: 20210317-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2021-03-16T11:09Z.

Estimated speed: ~514 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 31 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 165/-10 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-03-16T11:09:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Parker Solar Probe and OSIRIS-REx (minor impact).  The leading edge of the CME will reach Parker Solar Probe at 2021-03-18T19:08Z and OSIRIS-REx at 2021-03-19T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2021-03-16T11:09:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210316_192800_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210316_192800_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210316_192800_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210316_192800_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif

## Notes: 


SCORE CME typification system:

C-type: Common 500-999 km/s

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Continued elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2021-03-11T13:10Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2021-03-03T07:35Z are caused by combined effects of the high speed stream starting on 2021-03-02, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 690 km/s, and the high speed stream starting on 2021-03-05, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 600 km/s.  The solar wind speed observed at L1 is currently around 370 km/s.  (See notifications 20210303-AL-001, 20210303-AL-002, 20210305-AL-001, 20210307-AL-001, and 20210309-AL-001.)

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-03-03T07:35:00-RBE-001.

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 03, 2021 - March 09, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-03-10T20:13:58Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-03-03T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-03-09T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210310-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during the reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.

Geomagnetic activity reached minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 5 occurred during the synoptic periods 2021-03-03T00:00Z-09:00Z. The cause of this enhanced geomagnetic activity is associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2021-03-02, with solar wind speeds reaching values around 690 km/s on 2021-03-03.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was elevated above the threshold level of 1000 pfu throughout most of the reporting period (see notifications 20210303-AL-001, 20210303-AL-002, 20210305-AL-001, 20210307-AL-001, and 20210309-AL-001). These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2021-03-02 and may have been enhanced by the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2021-03-05, with solar wind speeds reaching values around 600 km/s on 2021-03-06.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the radiation belt enhancement mentioned above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-03-10T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-03-16T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. New Active Region 2808 developed on the Earth-facing disk near the end of the reporting period. There is one new active region due to rotate onto the Earth-facing disk in the next several days, as seen near latitude N20 on the eastern limb in STEREO-A EUVI imagery towards the end of the reporting period. Active Region 2808 produced one C-class flare and several B-class flares near the end of the reporting period and may produce several B-class flares, with the minor possibility for C-class flares, during the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity may vary between low and minor levels throughout the outlook period due to the possible influence of a coronal hole structure, which passed the Earth-facing meridian near the end of the reporting period. As seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO, this coronal hole structure is connected with the south pole coronal hole and may become geoeffective near the middle of the outlook period. In response to 2021-03-02 and 2021-03-05 high speed stream arrivals at L1, the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt remains elevated above the threshold level of 1000 pfu and may continue to be elevated during the early part of the outlook period.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-03-09T15:21:18Z
## Message ID: 20210309-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Continued elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2021-03-09T14:55Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2021-03-03T07:35Z are caused by combined effects of the high speed stream starting on 2021-03-02, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 690 km/s, and the high speed stream starting on 2021-03-05, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 600 km/s.  The solar wind speed observed at L1 is currently around 440 km/s.  (See notifications 20210303-AL-001, 20210303-AL-002, 20210305-AL-001, and 20210307-AL-001.)

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-03-03T07:35:00-RBE-001.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 24, 2021 - March 02, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-03-03T21:57:00Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-02-24T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-03-02T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210303-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during the reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.

Geomagnetic activity reached moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 6 occurred during the synoptic period 2021-03-01T03:00Z-06:00Z. The cause of this enhanced geomagnetic activity may be associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2021-02-28, with solar wind speeds reaching values around 535 km/s on 2021-03-01 (see notifications 20210301-AL-001 and 20210301-AL-003). The cause of this enhanced geomagnetic activity continues to be evaluated.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was elevated above the threshold level of 1000 pfu throughout much of the reporting period (see notifications 20210226-AL-001 and 20210228-AL-001). These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2021-02-19 and may also be associated with the arrival of two C-type CMEs at L1 observed on 2021-02-23 and 2021-02-24.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the radiation belt enhancement mentioned above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-03-03T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-03-09T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. New Active Regions 2806 and 2807 developed on the Earth-facing disk near the end of the reporting period. There are no new active regions due to rotate onto the Earth-facing disk in the next several days, as seen in STEREO-A EUVI imagery. Active Region 2807 may produce several B-class flares, with the slight possibility for C-class flares, during the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels throughout the outlook period due to the influence of an extensive coronal hole structure currently visible on the Earth-facing disk. Geomagnetic activity reached minor levels with Kp = 5 during the synoptic periods 2021-03-02T18:00Z-21:00Z and 2021-03-03T00:00Z-09:00Z. This increase in geomagnetic activity is associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2021-03-02, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 690 km/s. In response to this high speed stream, the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2021-03-03T07:35Z (see notifications 20210303-AL-001 and 20210303-AL-002). Electron flux levels may continue to remain elevated throughout the outlook period.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Summary:

Space weather storm observed in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2021-03-01T03:00Z to 2021-03-01T06:00Z. 

The storm is caused by a high speed stream observed on 2021-02-28.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

## Notes:

This event is associated with the Interplanetary Shock with ID 2021-02-28T23:03:00-IPS-001 (see notification 20210301-AL-002). The Kp index has decreased to 2 during the latest synoptic period, 2021-03-01T12:00Z to 2021-03-01T15:00Z.
